title: 110_s3466
content: The Act may be cited as the "Job Access and Reverse Commute Program Improvements Act of 2008". This Act pertains to the Job Access and Reverse Commute Program. The Act allows states to accept combined applications for projects using funds from multiple programs, with incentives such as reducing cost share requirements or increasing funds for administrative expenses. The Act allows states to accept combined applications for various transportation programs, including the elderly and disabled specialized transit program, the new freedom program, and other programs deemed appropriate by the Secretary under section 5316 of title 49, United States Code. The Act permits states to consolidate applications for different transportation programs, such as those for elderly and disabled specialized transit, new freedom program, and other programs designated by the Secretary under section 5316 of title 49, US Code. Additionally, it includes provisions for subsidizing transportation costs for low-income high school students and young adults attending career or technical education, job training, or apprenticeship programs. Operating assistance is capped at 80 percent of the net amount. The Act allows states to consolidate applications for various transportation programs and provides subsidies for transportation costs for low-income students. Operating assistance is capped at 80 percent of the net amount, with the option for states to transfer funds for eligible projects. Reporting and certification requirements may be streamlined by the Secretary. The Secretary may streamline reporting and certification requirements for transportation programs if the primary goals are met. A study will be conducted on reducing burden for nonprofit organizations. States are encouraged to use alternative assessment measures for transportation access improvements. The Secretary may conduct a pilot program to improve education and employment transportation for teens and young adults by linking high schools to technical colleges, job centers, and apprenticeships. Workforce boards will coordinate and review applications to streamline reporting requirements. The program aims to support comprehensive projects integrated with other transportation and human service programs while minimizing paperwork burden. The Department of Transportation collaborates with other federal departments to address comprehensive human service transportation needs, develop programs crossing local government boundaries, and involve multiple localities. Additionally, there is an authorization of $10,000,000 annually from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund for workforce development projects integrating transportation needs during training and job placement. The Secretary will continue and expand technical assistance and peer-to-peer network activities to support efforts in this area. The Department supports efforts such as acting as an information clearinghouse, providing technical assistance to grant applicants and recipients, conducting outreach and education on transportation assistance, and coordinating activities as needed. The Department of Transportation coordinates activities and support between related Federal programs, authorizing $2,000,000 for technical assistance and peer-to-peer network activities. This is part of the Job Access and Reverse Commute Formula Grants under Section 5338 of title 49, United States Code. The Job Access and Reverse Commute Formula Grants under Section 5316 of title 49, United States Code, will receive funding from the Mass Transit Account of the Highway Trust Fund, with increasing amounts allocated for fiscal years 2010 to 2014. Amounts made available will remain available until expended, and certain provisions will apply to unexpended amounts. Offsetting of unobligated funds authorized for projects under section 1602 of the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century is rescinded as of June 9, 2008.
